algorithms.imageProcessing

Class Gaussian1DSecondDeriv

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.imageProcessing.Gaussian1DSecondDeriv

  • public class Gaussian1DSecondDeriv
extends java.lang.Object
    NOTE: the binomial kernels here need to be reviewed again one day and possibly edited. class to retrieve a kernel for the first derivative of a gaussian of a given sigma. For the smaller sigma, curvature tests show that a binomial filter should be used instead of the detailed calculation of the formula due to errors in normalization due to the tails of the function. Therefore, the general methods are returning binomial filter curves when possible. Sometimes those have been edited from the binomial pattern due to centering.
    Author:
    nichole

    • Method Detail

      • getKernel

        public static float[] getKernel(SIGMA sigma,
                                float mu,
                                int nPoints)

      • getKernel

        public static float[] getKernel(float sigma,
                                float mu,
                                int nPoints)
        get the kernel for the given sigma and mu. nPoints is the number of points in the Gaussian kernel (determined by the approximate FWZI), so mu - half of nPoints determines the starting x in the kernel. the function is: 
                          (x - mu - sigma) * (x - mu + sigma)      ( -(x - mu)^2 )
       d^2fdx^2 = ----------------------------------- * exp( ----------- )
                         sigma^5 * sqrt(2*pi)              (    2o~^2    )
        To create the x-axis for the kernel: 
               int halfWidthInPixels = kernel.length >> 1; 
       int[] x = new int[kernel.length];
       for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
            x[i] = i + (int) (mu - halfWidthInPixels);
       }
        Parameters:
        sigma -
        mu -
        nPoints -
        Returns:

      • getKernel

        public static float[] getKernel(SIGMA sigma,
                                float mu)
        get the kernel for the given sigma and mu. the function is: 
                          (x - mu - sigma) * (x - mu + sigma)      ( -(x - mu)^2 )
       d^2fdx^2 = ----------------------------------- * exp( ----------- )
                         sigma^5 * sqrt(2*pi)              (    2o~^2    )
        To create the x-axis for the kernel: 
               int halfWidthInPixels = kernel.length >> 1; 
       int[] x = new int[kernel.length];
       for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
            x[i] = i + (int) (mu - halfWidthInPixels);

        public static float[] getKernel(float sigma,

      • getKernel

        public static float[] getKernel(float sigma)
        get the kernel for the given sigma. mu = 0 is used. the function is: 
                          (x - mu - sigma) * (x - mu + sigma)      ( -(x - mu)^2 )
       d^2fdx^2 = ----------------------------------- * exp( ----------- )
                         sigma^5 * sqrt(2*pi)              (    2o~^2    )
        To create the x-axis for the kernel: 
               int halfWidthInPixels = kernel.length >> 1; 
       int[] x = new int[kernel.length];
       for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
            x[i] = i + (int) (mu - halfWidthInPixels);
       }
        Parameters:
        sigma -
        Returns:

      • getKernel

        public static float[] getKernel(SIGMA sigma)
        get the kernel for the given sigma and deltaX. NOTE: working out whether an offset can be applied to results... has not been applied yet to allow re-use of the kernel, so when using this kernel, be sure to multiply each element by -(x-mu); the function is: 
                          (x - mu - sigma) * (x - mu + sigma)      ( -(x - mu)^2 )
       d^2fdx^2 = ----------------------------------- * exp( ----------- )
                         sigma^5 * sqrt(2*pi)              (    2o~^2    )
        To create the x-axis for the kernel: 
               int halfWidthInPixels = kernel.length >> 1; 
       int[] x = new int[kernel.length];
       for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
            x[i] = i + (int) (mu - halfWidthInPixels);
       }
        Parameters:
        sigma -
        Returns:
